translation.text: Basant, First Mehl:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

translation.text: The fickle consciousness cannot find the Lord's limits.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: It is caught in non-stop coming and going.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: I am suffering and dying, O my Creator.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਬਿਨੁ ਪ੍ਰੀਤਮ ਕੋ ਕਰੈ ਨ ਸਾਰਾ ॥੧॥

translation.text: No one cares for me, except my Beloved. ||1||

transliteration.text: bin prītam kō karai n sārā .1.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: All are high and exalted; how can I call anyone low?

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

text: ਹਰਿ ਭਗਤੀ ਸਚਿ ਨਾਮਿ ਪਤੀਨਾ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥

translation.text: Devotional worship of the Lord and the True Name has satisfied me. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: har bhagatī sach nām patīnā .1. rahāu .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

translation.text: I have taken all sorts of medicines; I am so tired of them.

text: ਕਿਉ ਦੁਖੁ ਚੂਕੈ ਬਿਨੁ ਗੁਰ ਮੇਰੇ ॥

translation.text: How can this disease be cured, without my Guru?

transliteration.text: kiu dukh chūkai bin gur mērē .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. translation.text: Without devotional worship of the Lord, the pain is so great.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. translation.text: My Lord and Master is the Giver of pain and pleasure. ||2||

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. translation.text: The disease is so deadly; how can I find the courage?

translation.text: He knows my disease, and only He can take away the pain.

translation.text: My mind and body are filled with faults and demerits.

translation.text: I searched and searched, and found the Guru, O my brother! ||3||

text: ਗੁਰ ਕਾ ਸਬਦੁ ਦਾਰੂ ਹਰਿ ਨਾਉ ॥

translation.text: The Word of the Guru's Shabad, and the Lord's Name are the cures.

transliteration.text: gur kā sabad dārū har nāu .

translation.text: As You keep me, so do I remain.

translation.text: The world is sick; where should I look?

translation.text: The Lord is Pure and Immaculate; Immaculate is His Name. ||4||

text: ਘਰ ਮਹਿ ਘਰੁ ਜੋ ਦੇਖਿ ਦਿਖਾਵੈ ॥

translation.text: The Guru sees and reveals the Lord's home, deep within the home of the self;

transliteration.text: ghar mah ghar jō dēkh dikhāvai .

text: ਮਨ ਮਹਿ ਮਨੂਆ ਚਿਤ ਮਹਿ ਚੀਤਾ ॥

translation.text: When the mind remains in the mind, and the consciousness in the consciousness,

transliteration.text: man mah manūā chit mah chītā .

translation.text: such people of the Lord remain unattached. ||5||

translation.text: tasting the Amrit, the Ambrosial Nectar, they abide in the Lord's Name.

translation.text: They recognize their own selves, and remain lovingly attuned to the Lord.

translation.text: They are victorious on the battlefield of life, following the Guru's Teachings, and their pains run away. ||6||

translation.text: The Guru has given me the True Ambrosial Nectar; I drink it in.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: Of course, I have died, and now I am alive to live.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: Please, protect me as Your Own, if it pleases You.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

translation.text: One who is Yours, merges into You. ||7||

translation.text: Painful diseases afflict those who are sexually promiscuous.

text: ਘਟਿ ਘਟਿ ਰਵਿ ਰਹਿਆ ਪ੍ਰਭੁ ਜਾਪੈ ॥

translation.text: God appears permeating and pervading in each and every heart.

transliteration.text: ghat ghat rav rahiā prabh jāpai .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. text: ਸੁਖ ਦੁਖ ਹੀ ਤੇ ਗੁਰ ਸਬਦਿ ਅਤੀਤਾ ॥

translation.text: One who remains unattached, through the Word of the Guru's Shabad

transliteration.text: sukh dukh hī tē gur sabad atītā .

translation.text: - O Nanak, his heart and consciousness dwell upon and savor the Lord. ||8||4||
